    Batchr Demonstration

    batchr-demo.Rmd

    Demonstration

    For the purposes of this demonstration let’s create a temporary directory with two csv files.

    path <- file.path(tempdir(), "demo")
unlink(path)
dir.create(path)

write.csv(data.frame(x = 1), file.path(path, "file1.csv"))
write.csv(data.frame(x = 3), file.path(path, "file2.csv"))

    Configuration

    The first task is for the user to configure a directory by specify the files to process and the function to process them with.

    library(batchr)

fun <- function(file) {
  data <- read.csv(file)
  data$y <- data$x * 2
  write.csv(data, file)
  TRUE
}

batch_config(fun, path = path, pattern = "^file\\d[.]csv$")

    Configuring a directory creates a hidden file (.batchr.rds) which can be read using batch_read_config()

    batch_config_files(path) # hidden file
#> [1] ".batchr.rds"
batch_read_config(path)
#> $time
#> [1] "2019-08-06 22:26:46 UTC"
#> 
#> $pattern
#> [1] "^file\\d[.]csv$"
#> 
#> $recursive
#> [1] FALSE
#> 
#> $fun
#> function(file) {
#>   data <- read.csv(file)
#>   data$y <- data$x * 2
#>   write.csv(data, file)
#>   TRUE
#> }
#> 
#> $dots
#> list()

    The time value specifies the system time (in UTC) that the project was configured. A file is only treated as unprocessed if the time it was last modified is before the time of configuration If a file is successfully processed its modification time is set to the current time; otherwise the name of the file is logged in the .batchr.log file.

    Start

    The next task is to start (or restart) processing the files using batch_start().

    batch_run(path, ask = FALSE)
